You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the balance of housing debt was nis 272 billion at the end of august, an increase of 6.9 percent since august of remained essentially unchanged, while interest rates in the unindexed variable rate segment again increased by about 0.1 percentage points, following a similar increase in august.\n \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: rates of interest on indexed fixed- and floating-interest-rate mortgages continued to decline, and those on unindexed floating-rate mortgages remained stable in the last few months.\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: share price indices fell, and credit risk premiums rose.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses market reactions (share price indices and credit risk premiums) without mentioning any monetary policy decisions or actions that influence monetary policy decisions."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: according to the monetary department's model, some depreciation of the shekel would return inflation to within the range.\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in addition, the monetary committee announced a targeted plan intended to assist the orderly granting of credit to small and micro businesses that were adversely impacted by the war.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: since the publication of the march cpi, nominal yields on short-term instruments have risen by about 0.4 percentage points.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:48:39,638 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The rise in nominal yields on short-term instruments indicates a tightening of monetary conditions, suggesting a hawkish stance."
}

the cpi, increased in november–december by 1 percent, after increasing by 1.1 percent in october–november.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on home price increases without mentioning any monetary policy actions or implications, making it neutral."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, they noted that activity was still at a low level, that the output gap was expected to continue widening, and that unemployment was expected to increase in the next few months.\n                "}]

\\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, the bank of israel notes that the slowdown in growth in the advanced economies, particularly the us, is expected to affect israel’s economy.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the last twelve months the housing price index increased by 6.5 percent, compared with increases of 5.9 percent in january and 4.5 percent in december.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on the housing price index without mentioning any monetary policy decisions or implications, making it neutral."

policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: exports of goods and services increased by 5.6 percent—after declines of 10 percent and 5 percent, respectively, in the previous two quarters— bringing the figure back to the level it was at in the first quarter of 2011.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. doubtful debts in respect of housing credit, the supervisor of banks published a draft directive increasing the required risk weighting and provisioning on housing loans, and reducing the required capital allocation for guarantees in respect of homes already delivered to residents.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: they claimed that the low level of the interest rate supports the continued recovery of economic activity.\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other
