Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: china also appears to be showing signs of a slowdown this month (relative to its terms of growth) with a drop in industrial production, in consumer sales, and its purchasing managers' index in the manufacturing sector.\n                "}]

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the financial markets reacted with stability to the events in the north.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence does not mention any specific monetary policy action or decision, and only reports on the reaction of financial markets to an event, without indicating any stance."

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the us, economic activity remained at a high level, and above the trend, and the labor market remained tight.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in november and december, there was a recovery in the scope of credit card purchases, with total purchases returning to a level similar to that in routine times, except for the tourism industry.\n                "}]

is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the average rate of unemployment is expected to be 6.1 percent in 2008.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:49:17,556 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply reports a forecasted unemployment rate without indicating any policy stance or action."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: one member stated that he was not concerned about a continued rise in home prices, but just the opposite, a too rapid drop in their prices.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: three of the participants recommended cutting the interest rate by 0.25 percentage points.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a recommendation to lower the interest rate, which is a sign of an accommodative or easing monetary policy stance."
}

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the impact on home prices of the ltv ratio limitations, which were imposed by the supervisor of banks and went into effect at the beginning of november, was not reflected in december mortgage data, but is expected to be seen beginning in january.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the tel aviv 25 index fell by 14 percent, a move similar to that of us stock market indices.\n                "}]

responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the rate of reduction in unit labor costs has moderated, however.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides a neutral observation about the moderation of unit labor costs without indicating any specific stance or policy direction."

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the us economy grew by 3 percent in the fourth quarter, the highest rate of increase since the second quarter of consumer confidence, retail sales, and manufacturing data in the us all indicate expansion.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the official reason for the announcement was the impression created of the difficulty of leaders of the eurozone and the eu to make decisions, which indicates an inherent weakness in the decision making process.\n                "}]

economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the growth rate of business credit in recent months has been lower than in the period prior to the war, and the most recent figures business sector declined slightly.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:49:44,990 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports on a neutral fact about the growth rate of business credit without indicating any change in monetary policy stance or direction."
}
