\\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a summary view of the economic situation available at the time of the committee’s discussion is presented in the [notice regarding the interest rate decision, which was](https://www.boi.org.il/en/newsandpublications/pressreleases/pages/28-8-19.aspx) the members of the monetary committee participating in the discussion decide on the appropriate rate of interest.\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: therefore, the monetary policy will have to remain accommodative in order to support economic recovery.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the monetary policy will remain accommodative to support economic recovery, indicating a readiness to ease monetary conditions."

2025-05-03 18:49:55,546 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Bank of Israel\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: based on the equation, the cpi housing component (i.e., rentals) is expected to rise faster than was estimated previously.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies a potential increase in inflation, which may lead to a tighter monetary policy stance."

with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the expected short-term real interest rate has been on a rising trend since february the bank of israel interest rate.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies a rising trend in the short-term real interest rate, which suggests a tightening of monetary policy, indicating a hawkish stance."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the contrasting developments of the domestic price component and the import price component in shekels stress the high contribution of the shekel's appreciation to the low inflation rate.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it can be assumed that upcoming elections are likely to continue the paralysis of the leadership there in its ability to deal with the crisis.\n                "}]

\nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the fed continues with its quantitative easing measures.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:50:09,621 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the central bank is maintaining an accommodative stance by continuing quantitative easing measures, which is a sign of a dovish policy."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: interest rates on new fixed rate, cpi-indexed mortgages declined in april, while the interest rate on variable rate mortgages remained stable.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The decline in interest rates on new fixed rate, cpi-indexed mortgages indicates a slight easing of monetary conditions, making borrowing more affordable."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: these participants thought that it was important to reduce the interest rate by a larger amount this month so that the rate of price increases would be more likely to become consistent with the target inflation rate sooner rather than later.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:50:17,175 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests reducing the interest rate to stimulate the economy and achieve the target inflation rate sooner, indicating an accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: against the background of these developments, the ecb made a surprise cut in the interest rate this month, and the markets are pricing in interest rate cuts in other economies.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:50:19,880 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a surprise cut in the interest rate, which is a dovish action, and also implies that other economies may follow suit, indicating a accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the figures published in the us during the month showed a continued slowdown in growth, and in the second quarter the rate (in annual terms) was only 1 percent, significantly lower than the expected rate of 1.8 percent, and the figure for the first quarter was adjusted sharply downwards, from 1.9 percent to only 0.4 percent.\n                "}]

2025-05-03 18:50:28,523 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Bank of Israel\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: eurozone inflation is expected to be 2.7 percent in 2011, and 2 percent in 2012.\n                "}]

with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on 4 december the bank of england cut its rate from 3 percent to 2 percent, and on 19 december the bank of japan reduced its rate by 0.2 percentage points to 0.1 percent.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the Bank of England and the Bank of Japan, not the Bank of Israel, and therefore is not relevant to the Bank of Israel's monetary policy meeting."

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3.
